Well I don't see anything in any page. I am new to skywalking so I am suspecting a wrong configuration somewhere. When I make a new service request, all I can see is the service count gets incremented in dashboard. But in services tab, there is one empty entry. But I can select it. And it throws error saying `Variable 'applicationId' has coerced Null value for NonNull type 'ID!'`
First, make sure there are requests to your monitored services. Then, check whether this is data in ES. Last, make sure your machine(VM) time and timezone settings are right.

- There are requests I am making to my monitored service
- Elastic I can see lots of indices created. Not sure which one specifically should I check
- Since my application and collector are on same host for now, I hope I can rule out the possibility of timezone setting

> Elastic I can see lots of indices created. Not sure which one specifically should I check

See `application_*`, `jvm*`.

> Since my application and collector are on same host for now, I hope I can rule out the possibility of timezone setting

Is the host your local machine? Browser should be in the same time zone.

Thanks wu-sheng. That helped. After some time the data came up. I hope the issue was the browser machine and the deployment machines were not same. It works after some time. One more issue I am facing is, now the application/service and topology tabs are not getting populated. I can see individual traces though
Could you provide the trace screenshot? In most cases, you need to try to pinpoint the cause.

yes,  trace uplinks. 
zipkin server doesn't support, so that each tracing data require one http interaction,  that is too much for a service to deal with high concurrency requests

Thanks for your feedback. I am closing this. Let's hope dubbo 2.7.0 release will not bring this issue back.

`ContextManager.createEntrySpan` that is the magic. Entry span will merge all existing entry span in the active stack automatically. This is for performance concern, but the duration is the first span's.

I don't know what happens to your DCClient span. Is that span is a child of another exit span? From your trace snapshot, I can't find out.

I just simply invoke a HTTP request, in the Http request method , it invokes a RPC .
So The DCClient span(Exit Span) is a child of "Spring MVC" Span (Entry Span).
Exit span would not merge into entry span. Then, most likely, does the exit span in other thread, and you don't link them together.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7646548/44139481-cc0384a4-a0a9-11e8-9925-295d27953384.png)


The active span stack.at the time. The Entry span (SPringMVC) and the exit span (DCClient) are in a same thread. The DCServer is at other process.

> The active span stack.at the time. The Entry span (SPringMVC) and the exit span (DCClient) are in a same thread. The DCServer is at other process.

That explains a lot of things. First, the trace is `DCServer` related, so clearly no SPringMVC and DCClient. They are not disappeared, they are in another trace.
But the active trace stack is at the side of DCClient (invoker side).
I mean you need to figure your thread things by yourself. In my perspective, all span should be in single thread. Only a few, like gRPC(because nio/netty), they need to deal with multiple threads.

> all span should be in single thread
 
In my opinion, The ExitSpan will be recorded in the Invoker side ,and send some traceinfo payload to other side (DCServer side). And then DCServer side build the spans on basis of payload received.
I'm sorry i dont get your point of "all span should be in single thread". you mean in the invoker side I must add the Entry span (Dcserver) to the trace?  or in the DCServer side I build all spans ?

> In my opinion, The ExitSpan will be recorded in the Invoker side ,and send some traceinfo payload to other side (DCServer side). And then DCServer side build the spans on basis of payload received.
I'm sorry i dont get your point of "all span should be in single thread". you mean in the invoker side I must add the Entry span (Dcserver) to the trace? or in the DCServer side I build all spans ?

Let's say you have an incoming HTTP request like this:

`HTTP -> [DCServerA, DCClientA] -> RPC -> [DCServerB]`

I mean in this case spans of `DCServerA, DCClientA` should be a single thread. `DCServerB` span should be in another thread(process) clearly.

In global, there should be two segments.

> I mean in this case spans of DCServerA, DCClientA should be a single thread. DCServerB span should be in another thread(process) clearly.

Now the DCServerA, DCClientA are in a single thread. But they disappeared! And at this graph I
just want to show the two spans I had in the trace context.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7646548/44139481-cc0384a4-a0a9-11e8-9925-295d27953384.png)

I mean spans would not disappear, that is not true. If the root span `EntrySpan` finished, the segment will be sent to the backend. If ExitSpan put the context in headers, the other side received and reffed, the trace will continue. That is all. 

You need to find out
1. Whether this active stack finished as expected? and do finish notification.
1. Does the other side received the `sw3` headers, which includes valid headers.
Thx. The second point : the other side did received the sw3 headers. First point I need to confirm.
English only. Javaagent can't boot by itself. It is an attachment for you main.

>  1. Whether this active stack finished as expected? and do finish notification.

According to the program's invoke stack, The "Finish notification" did happened.As below graph:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7646548/44185996-6ee53600-a149-11e8-8230-9ca750b1db7a.png)

The "finishedSegment" above at that time included two spans - "Entry"(SpringMVC ) and "Exit"
(DCClient), "finishedSegment" 's context as below:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7646548/44186030-a522b580-a149-11e8-826c-fb696bff45ff.png)

Into the "notifyFinish" method. There are three listeners. As below:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7646548/44186090-f468e600-a149-11e8-8bd2-fb7c6d3cb9dd.png)

All Context Info  above I get so far. Is it enough to help to analyze the reason in this case? @wu-sheng

This is not related to qps. This is a warning, means too many spans in a single one request trace. The most likely reason is, there is trace leak.

What does your trace look like normally? How many spans?

@ylywyn Because the `Response` and `Request`  are not stored in `RuntimeContext` at the same time, please see [InvokeForRequestInterceptor](https://github.com/apache/incubator-skywalking/blob/master/apm-sniffer/apm-sdk-plugin/spring-plugins/mvc-annotation-commons/src/main/java/org/apache/skywalking/apm/plugin/spring/mvc/commons/interceptor/InvokeForRequestInterceptor.java) and [GetBeanInterceptor.java](https://github.com/apache/incubator-skywalking/blob/master/apm-sniffer/apm-sdk-plugin/spring-plugins/mvc-annotation-commons/src/main/java/org/apache/skywalking/apm/plugin/spring/mvc/commons/interceptor/GetBeanInterceptor.java), so I think that The `Response` interceptor is not in effect in some version. Could you give the demo to reproduce  this issue. or you can check if the `Response`  is stored in the `RuntimeContext`
